meaning_mnemonic: There is a stool sticking out of the dirt. You walk up and realize it has writing on it. It's actually a <radical>tombstone</radical>. You can sit on it and remember the people who are below the dirt now.

In winter, your mouth longs for a <radical>kiss</radical>. You know, because your lips get cold and you want someone to warm them up. How do you think that whole mistletoe thing got started? Cold winter mouths, longing for a kiss. So just imagine the top part of this radical as some winter mistletoe (or holly leaves, since that's probably easier), and the bottom part as a kissy mouth.

This radical has a bean (the square in the middle) between the ground and some roots. That bean is going to turn into a plant someday. What will that plant produce? Great big <radical>beans</radical>, like the ones from Jack and the Beanstalk.

This looks like the west radical with a little something extra under it… And if you ask for "a little something extra" in the Wild West, you're going to get a big ol' decanter of bourbon, moonshine, or some other kind of very strong <radical>alcohol</radical> — which happens to be exactly what this radical looks like! That extra line at the bottom is just the little bit of alcohol still left in the bottle.
If you kick a cliff twice you'll start a <radical>landslide</radical>! Oh no!

A leaf-shaped protrusion coming out of a shellfish. What is it? The mysterious <radical>geoduck</radical>! The geoduck is a giant clam so big that most of it grows outside its shell. If you've never seen a geoduck, look it up now. You'll never be able to unsee it.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>music</radical>! 曲 even looks like a musical score with two notes in the middle. Huh? Real sheet music has more lines, you say? Hey, it's a radical — we're saving ink, not performing Beethoven here.

Alternatively, you could use the kanji mnemonic you learned: There are twenty mouths singing beautiful music together.
Doesn't this radical look like one of those old-fashioned <radical>dynamite</radical> plunger things that gets pushed to set the fuse? That makes this dynamite!

This is the canopy radical with ice running down the back. If you hang out in a cold canopy like this you'll definitely get <radical>sick</radical>. Imagine being sick and alone inside a cold canopy. Brrrr, oh no... ACHOO!

This radical looks like a little flight of <radical>stairs</radical>, don't you think? Also note it's being held up by a pillar or beam or something on the left side. After all, you don't want your stairs collapsing as you walk up them.

This looks like a tree with something tied around its middle, holding it tight. If you untied that middle part you'd realize it's actually a bunch of little trees (aka twigs and sticks) tied in a <radical>bundle</radical>!
This is the <radical>turkey</radical> radical. It kinda looks like a turkey facing to the left, with big tail feathers fanning out behind it. See it? You can practically hear this thing gobble!

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>fault</radical>.

Just in case you don't remember the kanji's meaning mnemonic, here's the gist: That slide is your husband's only <kanji>fault</kanji>. He spends all day sliding down it like a madman, which is why his hair sticks straight up on top. Maybe that's another fault… It's also a way to remember this is 失 (fault), not 矢 (arrow).

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>sell</radical>.

Just in case you don't remember, here's the kanji meaning mnemonic: A samurai has come bearing foreheads and legs that he's trying to <kanji>sell</kanji>. He thought it was a waste to leave all his slain enemies on the battlefield, so he gathered up their foreheads and legs to sell on the black market for some extra cash. Hey, no judging! A samurai's gotta sell what a samurai's gotta sell, okay?
This is the <radical>pope</radical> radical. Why? Because it looks like a pope hat! This one's got a big old cross on top, and it can only be worn by the pope.

This is the <radical>Chinese</radical> radical. Why? Because it looks like a traditional Chinese pagoda! One of those towers with a bunch of tiered roofs, you know? Sure, lots of Asian countries have pagodas, but let's be honest — the Chinese probably came up with them first.

Oh no, you let the pope's hat get snatched by a lion! You get it back, but it's all crooked, so you've got to make it <radical>straight</radical> again. The pope needs a straight, dignified hat, so you'd better straighten that thing out.
